conclusion: The problem involves analyzing how shadows A, B, C, and D change in position and size when the light source moves backward above the objects.
The image shows four objects above a slab: a hat, a glove, a peach, and a calendar, each casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D respectively.
The shadows A, B, C, and D are cast on the ground and are positioned in different locations relative to their respective objects.
When the light source moves farther back, each shadow shifts forward (away from the light source).
When the light source moves farther back, each shadow becomes longer (larger) on the ground.
The farther-back light means the rays that reach the ground meet it at a shallower angle, causing the point where each ray intersects the floor to move forward.
The shallower angle of the rays translates into longer shadows.
All four shadows A, B, C, and D slide forward and lengthen.
Because the light shift is global, the relative order of the shadows (left to right) does not change.
Shadow A moves forward and increases in length.
Shadow B moves forward and increases in length.
Shadow C moves forward and increases in length.
Shadow D moves forward and increases in length.
